title: Ball joint - Cheap and more reliable alternative to Magnetic joints

description.text:
Very nice alternative to magnetic joints.

  • Cheap, just print and glue (compatible with any effector or carriage that uses a 12mm round magnetic)
  • Much stronger than a magnet joint
  • If you have a ball stud rods (10mm) you can use them, just press fit
  • If you wish you can print the male ball joint to glue in your 6mm rods, but you need to acetone vapor the thing to have a smooth movement, I tested only with steel ball studs.
  • Easy and fast to change tools
  • No backlash

title: MyRCCar Steering System for three different bearings: 5x8x4, 5x10x4 and 6x12x4

description.text:
This is a simple steering system without servo saver by now... It's obviously designed to by used with MyRCCar Universal Chassis and MyRCCar F/R Diff Housing.

I have designed 3 versions for 3 diferent bearing sizes: 5x8x4, 5x10x4 and 6x12x4. If you plan to build the whole car you will need many 5x10x4 bearings so i recommend you to choose the design appropriated for them.

As you can see there are no links to the steering blocks or servo arm. This parts should be adjustable so i plan to use links other people made or create my own if they don't fit my needs.

So 5 parts this time to print. Two pivots, both towers and the plate. With this set and some adjusting to the links you will be able to set the steering to your needs. I also plan to make a little different tower arms in the future if someone suggests it's needed.

One more time, if you have some questions about this thing please leave a comment. If your question would be related more to the whole proyect please join the MyRCCar Group. I hope i see you there soon building your own rc car:)

This mount makes it easy to attach a small limit switch (with 9.5mm on-center mounting hole spacing) to the bolt head of one of the Z-axis bearings of an MPCNC.

Depending on the size of the spindle you have mounted, there may not be clearance to fit a micro-switch there, so check, first.

Max-limit switches are useful for CNC homing, especially if using grbl as your MPCNC firmware.

This mount fits over a 1/2" bolt head, and has 4mm nut traps for the limit switch mounting. I found it easier to put the limit switch mounting screws in from the inside (so the screw length is not important, they just poke out through the limit switch), so I did not use the small nut traps.

The stock MPCNC tool mount depresses the limit switch as it moves up. I found that a limit switch with a wheel was necessary because of the extra 2mm of length it provides. A normal lever micro-switch wasn't quite long enough to activate reliably.

Rotate the bolt head so that the limit switch body is slightly angled up and the limit switch arm is roughly horizontal. This both maximizes your homed z-height (by a few mm), and puts the micro-switch arm more directly in the path of the tool mount.

I put a small bit of glue on the bolt head to hold this in place securely, but if I ever need to disassemble it, I can still pop it off.

Don't forget strain relief on the wires! I used these: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1800896 printed at 75% scale, with a bit of CA glue to hold them on.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lqXWdd5QCjv

Imagine you're just typing away on your keyboard when you spot something out of the corner of your eye. You look over at what you saw and BAM! Due to you being distracted, you've gotten your finger stuck under one of the keys. In a desperate attempt to free yourself, you start struggling but that just makes it worse. Eventually, you pull away so hard that the end of your finger is ripped away from the rest of your hand. With blood spurting and and arms failing, you realize you should have never looked to see what you saw in the corner of your eye. These glasses prevent you from having peripheral vision thus preventing any accidents.

I created this and mounted it on my coffee table, so I can get easy access to it, but doesn't occupy the space on my coffee table. I use the keyboard with the TV.

It is a two pieces print, so you can print it and use it with any size keyboard.
CAUTION: they are not semitrical, on side is wider than the other to cater for the bend on the keyboard, you may need to import it to any 3D design app and adjust it for your need.

Please comment for any help/information required.
Peace..

title: X-Axis Parts for Zaribo and Prusa MK3

description.text:
UPDATE 26.02.2018: The following files have been upated

x-MotorHolder-1x-2.1
x-Idler-1x-2.1
x-BeltTensioner-Part2-1x-2.1
x-BeltTensioner-Part1-1x-2.1

NOTE: The pulley needed is a 16T (the stock one is 20T)

There was a mix-up o files with different depth of holes for the rods. And an easier to print belt tensioner has been introduced.

This is the new x-axis for Zaribo MK3☺️ The parts are 100% compatible with Prusa MK3. In the new design the belt runs parallel and has no more tilting or slipping issues.

Thanks to Jon Madden for his great idea with belt tensioner and his work on the x-carriage for the MK2. The current parts are based on that.

The x-carriage features a new way of fastening the belt.
The new x-motor holder has some new features supported holder for the threaded rods
two little "windows" on the back to check proper rod insertion a little cutout makes rods insertion much easier without any drilling.
It prevents filament from "falling down" during printing and making the holes a bit smaller
a new way for cable management.
Original parts by Jon Madden: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2770019 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2770105
More information on Zaribo can be found on http://zaribo.org/ or on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/284271408664100/?ref=bookmarks

comments.text: Wolfgang,  you need to remove the fillet on the back edge of both X ends as this serves as the Z calibration reference against the screw heads on the Z frame.  This is a critical dimension.  In general, you should not fillet against the bed in FDM printing, but in particular not this edge.
comments.author: jltx

comments.text: At least on MK2/MK2(S)/MK3/Zaribo the x-ends DON'T hit the screws as calibration. The top of the x-parts are supposed to hit the bottom part of the z-holders. If a fillet would be critical it would be a bad design.
comments.author: jltx

comments.text: Nice prints.  I should have said "not advisable" about the fillet.  You are correct that you can achieve good results with a small radius fillet like you have.  A chamfer is more predictable in that orientation.

description.text: Office supply cup to the theme of stranger things. Includes a circular base and cup with 5 parts around covered in teeth. Watch your hand as you reach for your valued paper clips etc.

Project #4: Office Supply Storage

Problem Statement:
Recent analysis by the Staples finance department has concluded that sales for desktop organization products have declined in recent years. The company would like to ramp up their profits in this area by enhancing the aesthetic nature of these products.
Your group of two has been hired to design a set of theme-based organizational products. Your team will design a set of office supplies that are tied together with a common theme. You must be able to justify the theme that connects the products together. The idea is that the customer will not want to buy just one; they will want to buy the whole set.
OPTIONS:
Pen/Pencil holder that can securely hold at least 5 pencils
Expo marker holder than can securely hold at least 4 markers
Tape dispenser that will hold and cut a roll of scotch tape
Paper clips/etc. dish
Phone docking station
USB Stick/SD card holder
Custom Paper Clips
Anything you can get approved by your project manager!

Constraints:
You will be constructing an actual size model of your product in Solidworks
It should be cool to look at and unique - a conversation starter. An individual walking by would do a double take to more closely examine the amazingly interesting item you’ve created.
It should contain examples of ALL FOUR main features: extrusion, revolve, sweep, loft
It takes advantage of at least one of the following: circular pattern, linear pattern, mirror
It takes advantage of at least one of the following: filleting, chamfering
Each piece you design should fit within a 10cm x 10cm x 10cm cube
Should be 3D printable with limited/no supports

Deliverables (Each of the following steps must be approved by me before moving to the next step):
3D and 2D sketches of your ideas (upload pictures)
Planning for Solidworks “How-To” (Design Notebook)
Bulleted Outline on Google Docs
Use the pencil planning document as a template
Solidworks: Actual size model of your product
Thingiverse pages for each design
https://www.thingiverse.com/MCDeltaT/collections/office-supply-organizer-inspiration/
https://www.thingiverse.com/MCDeltaT/collections/office-supply-organizer-projects/

STEM Merit Badges are perfect for recognizing student participation in STEM camps, workshops and demonstrations. STEM activities are designed to interest students in careers in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics.  
A 3D printed STEM merit badges is a great take away and provides a tactile prompt for students to imagine themselves as scientists, engineers, programmers, designers and inventors.  
These STEM merit badges were awarded to hundreds of students in the summer of 2013 and are themed to match different grade level programs. The badges were printed in different colors for each team in a grade level program. The hurricane badges were for the natural disasters program. The fish badges were for the biological adaptations program. The rocket badge were for the robotics/rockets program.  
Please leave a comment or contact me on Twitter @DesignMakeTeach or on Facebook at Facebook.com/DesignMakeTeach. I love to talk with teachers, designers and makers about 3D printing, STEM and Learning by Making.

Vector clipart images were opened in Inkscape. The STEM letters were rotated and sized over the vector image. The text was selected and the Path-->Objects to Path command was used to convert the text. The clipart and letters were then combined Path-->Union. The file was then saved as an SVG. The SVG file was then imported into Tinkercad.  
Printed on a Printbot in PLA with a 0.2mm layer height.

Coming from a Tech2C's Hypercube, this is an attempt to add the vitamins of a Prusa i3 MK2 to it.

First attempt was to use the dual-Z drive, to stabilize the print bed. Motors, rods and bearings from the MK2 are used. For this, all STLs are in the project.

The Hypercube is having an aluminium extrusion height of 500mm, I am optimizing the space to use as much of the drive length as possible.

I try to design the parts so they are not dependent on 4 points, but reduce to triangular where possible to improve stability.

Heatbed

In an attempt to reuse as much as possible, I thought about using the main rod construction from the Prusa as base for the heatbed. Maybe some day ..

You will need to print

  • 4x z-rod-ext-v3.stl
  • 2x z-motor-rod-mount.stl
  • 2x z-carriage-mount-v2.stl
  • 2x z-carriage-drive.stl

From the Prusa, take 6x bearings, 4 rods (the longer ones).

  • 2x 290mm 2020 extrusion (like orig Hypercube)
  • 2x 135mm 2020 extrusion (one more than Hypercube)

The bottom motor and rod mount fits the heatbed mount.

Update 20180223: added y-rod holder, never had as too much trust in the Tech2C, even when they did what they had to do. It is a strong fit just by the rods, let's check if that is sufficent or if it wears out over time.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eQQB7twNVa4

title: Prusa I3 MK3 Y axis Adjustable Belt Tensioner

description.text:
Update 3/10/18 - I used jzkmath model of the assembled prusa i3 mk3 with the r2 components and found that the tensioner still works with the r2 belt holder, maintaining a belt path that is still parallel to the bed.

Update 2/28/18 - Please refer to the picture of the two parts in Slic3r that I have uploaded. This is the proper orientation for printing the parts so that there is no need for supports.

After a lot of design reviews and changes I've finally landed on a design that I think you will all like. It is simple and works like a charm. It is available to those using the stock idler (although I'd strongly advise an upgrade to a dual bearing unit), a gt2-16t idler (no more than 8.4mm wide) or a gt2-20t idler(no more than 8.4mm wide). When downloading the STL files, please be sure to select the proper file. They are all named according to the idler you wish to use. In addition to that, the 3D parts are embossed with "s" for stock idler, "16" for 16 tooth idler and of course "20" for 20 tooth idler. The Y axis adjuster arm is standard across the three choices.
This only requires some additional hardware which is listed below but requires no modifications to the printer itself. It can be used in conjunction with any motor mount solution that retains the stock motor mounting position and it must be used with any belt holder that retains the stock belt location dimensions (stock belt holder is more than sufficient).
When inspecting any misalignment issues on the 3D assembly of the Prusa i3 mk3 created by jzkmath, I found that there was .5mm misalignment between the motor pulley and the belt holder. I strongly believe that this very minor misalignment does not warrant printing a new belt holder or motor mount. Going forward with my design I wanted to be able to mate up with the stock belt holder while maintaing great alignment and parallelism between the belt and the carriage. This tensioner maintains perfect belt alignment throughout the entire adjustment travel since the pulley never moves vertically.
This has been tested on a Prusa i3 mk3 (thanks jweaver!) and fits beautifully with no interference issues, perfect belt parallelism (by eye) and gives the end user the ability to finely tune the tension on the belt. BINGO.

Hardware needed:
-M3x35mm socket head cap screws (2 pieces)
-M3x30mm socket head cap screws (1 piece)
-M3 Nylock nut (3 pieces)
-your choice of idler pulley

assembly instructions:

  1. Place the Y axis adjuster arm over and onto the idler frame mount leaving the slot for the Nylock nut facing out. Using one M3x35mm socket head cap screw and one Nylock nut to secure the adjuster arm onto the idler frame mount at the pivot point. DO NOT overtighten this as the adjuster needs to be able to pivot.
  2. Using your pulley of choice, place it into the idler frame mount mounting ears and align the idler bearing, mounting ear and slot on the side of the adjuster arm. Using one M3x35mm socket head cap screw, insert it all the way through the three items and use one M3 nylock nut. Again, DO NOT overtighten this as the adjuster needs to be able to pivot.
  3. Insert one M3 Nylock nut into the adjuster arm slot and using one M3x30mm socket head cap screw, insert through the ear on the idler frame mount and into the adjuster arm catching the Nylock nut.
  4. Install two Nylock nuts into the provided hex holes. At this point you are reusing the Nylock nuts that came with the printer.
  5. Install assembled belt tensioner with the pivot point towards the top. During belt tensioning it is important to refer to the manual as to the specific tension required. A simple adjustment of the M3x30mm screw will be all that is needed for tensioning.
    please refer to pictures for assembled tensioner.

Enjoy!

The Applause Machine is an Automata that I designed and build for a school project. I first started in Solidworks and created an assemble in which all the parts are mated so they can move together in order to make the hands clap at different times. Once the assembly was finished, I then laser cut out all the pieces on 1/4 inch thick wood. The pieces were then assembled and glued together. Although, the design works in Solidworks, due to the friction caused by the wood on wood pieces, it did not allow the machine to work every time. In the future, if I were to use different materials, such as acrylic, that would produce less friction, the Applause Machine may work more smoothly than it currently does.

Here is a link to how the Automata works:
https://youtu.be/TBQ0NwiNMT4

description.text:
My daughter wanted the Sword of Daylight from Trollhunters. I'm new to 3D printing so I took it on as a learning project. Modeled in Fusion 360 I made it to fit on a 1/2 inch wood dowel that is 25.6 inches long. I made little connectors to strengthen the seams. When I put mine together, not all connectors ended up fitting so I just put one in per seam. I think it had to do with a little distortion in the base of each print. The seam where both connecting sides were on top of the print they fit perfectly. If I did this again I'd print the blade pieces on a raft to try to help that issue. I printed 6 connectors but ended up using only 4. 15% infill seems to have been good enough for strength.

The only part that needs supports is the hilt. I made the inner holes have 45 degree angles. I glued the pieces together then blended the seams with Bondo and sanded. I didn't have time to finish it as nice as I would have liked. In the end she wanted it painted like the Sword of Eclipse.

This is a monster of a print. I think all pieces printed in a total time of around 45 hours. The picture of the pieces is how I oriented the prints.

Final coat of Krylon Clear Matte Finish to protect it. Had I done the Sword of Daylight I would have made the metallic coat solid. description.text:
So, since I have moved up to a larger size aquarium now my little filter bubblers is not getting the job done. SO I wanted to go industrial! Sort of. I quickly realized that a filter bag was the way to go for me but I had trouble finding them here and it was impossible to find any mounting options at all. So I made my own!

Size: Used for bags with a 100 mm Diameter. Inlet port is for 1cm hoses and tapered to accept slightly bigger ones too. I used a 20% infill, the shells alone should make it waterproof but I want with 20 to make it quite beefy.

How to use: Just slide the ring up to the flange of the bag, make sure it fits your filter, as some filters vary in size even though they are specified at one size... (Ask me how I know this.). Place the cone part on top of the ring and just zip tie both parts together in the 4 clasps and it makes a pretty darn good seal on its own. Connect it to a pump with a 10mm hose and it's done!

Recommendations: I use a pump with a high flow but quite poor static pressure. I've tried 100 and 200 micron bags but even the 200 micron bags gets clogged quite fast so see if you can find something with bigger holes. I'm currently working on a design to utilize filter wadding inside the bags to get a stage filtration but it's not beta tested yet. This setup works for about a week and then you have to wash the filter, but in return, it removes a crapload of crap.

(Holes for the Wires not in may Print as I forget them but have been added for the files on here) the Lid then Snaps in pale to house it all. This box will fit in a 32mm Diameter Pipe.

The Top Pins of the Arduino need to be Removed or a Hole added in your Software if you want.

description.text:
After putting together your anet a8, you may have realized that the Y axis belt runs in a triangle. the mounting point to the bed is too high, so the belt can't run in a straight line from the motor to the pulley/belt tensioner.
This fixes that.

The belt running in a triangle, causes the bed to travel different lengths, depending on how far it is from one of the edges, it should move the same distance regardless of its position.

The clamp has precisely modeled GT2 belt profile grooves, to grip the belt as well as possible, you only need to insert ~5 'bumps' on the belt for it hold. Remember to screw it down hard enough. Inset the belt on each side, so that there are 1 or 2 grooves left in between.

You can reuse the original screws, they're just long enough.

description.text:
Is this just a other 3D printed ukulele? Will this be great first bigger 3D printing project? Will this be great first instrument? Will teach you new thing about string instruments? Will this ukulele change the way you see the World? I sure hope so!

The key design point of this ukulele was to make it 3D printable, so design has taken account of limitations and possibilities 3D printing gives to designer! This ukulele requires only 200 mm printing area, so it can be printed with normal Prusa i3 or any other smaller 3D printer. And it is only 5 printed parts + string and tuners to play this ukulele. There is also option to place piezo pickup to make electric Travelele.

Main frame of Travelele is 3 parts, frame, neck and truss rod. This ukulele has frame adjustment method similar used is guitars called truss rod, so one can have much more adjustment on instrument. Truss rod attaches frame and neck together allows one more adjustment to instrument, with truss rod you can adjust angle of the ukulele neck relative to body and get the string gap perfect with the adjustments of nut and bridge.

This project is great introduction to string instruments and easy and great way to learn more about them, hardware for this ukulele can be bought less than 10€ and plastic costs are close to same.

If you have any questions about Travelele or ideas how to improve current design, Please contact me! i´m happy to hear what you think!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

30 - 40 %

Notes:

All parts was printed in the orientation .stl files are.

All parts were printed using Prusa i3 Mk2s and original 0.4mm nozzle. I used 0.3mm layer height and 220°C extruder temperature and 55°C bed temperature, with cooling fan on.

Frame, neck and rod was printed using 40% Infill but little less or more will do just fine. I recommend printing frame and neck with built-in supports if you use additive printing. Slicer generated supports can be little difficult and can block smaller details and usually generate really much waste and cleanup.

Nut and bridge was printed using 100% infill.

After you have printed all Travelele parts its time to assembly. Assembling frame and neck is really straightforward, you just insert neck to the frame part and drop truss rod in its pocket and install screw. Screw should not be tightened like normal screws, this screw is for adjusting angle of the neck so you can adjust string gap to your liking. For now, just gently tighten the screw and you are ready to install tuners and strings.

Tuning pegs i used and designed Travelele to use are just cheap ebay tuners "Ukulele Strings Tuning Pegs" ones with some fiber friction washer. Tuners are easy to install and screws do not need to be tighten for now, i find it easier to tight them when i have installed the strings.

If you have got yourself piezo pickup for ukulele great time to install it now, or later and practise tuning ukulele little more:) Piezo goes in a little slot under the bridge and cable comes out of back. Installing piezo is easy, just cut the wire, feed the wire thrue the hole and put piezo in its hole and install the strings. Good practice is to install some kind of straing relif to save cable. Now just solder connector you can use with your amp and you are ready to go.

Strings i used are just some 1€ ukulele nylon strings from ebay. Strings i got had no markings of which is which or how to install them. Normal order of ukulele strings is GCEA, so if 1 is fattest string and 4 is thinnest order from left to right or up to down should be 3124.

Now that strings are on places but not tuned its time to check is string gap is good. It should be close but now is time to adjust it if you need. From the first fret gap should be 0,5 - 1 mm and 2-3 mm at the last fret. If gap is too much from the last fret you can afjust it by tightening truss rod, and when you get that close you can file down nut or bridge to get it closet to your linking. Normally you should not need to file down nut or bridge, just just the truss rod screw and get gap good from the last fret.

Now your Travelele is ready and its time to tune strings, this can be done easy by using mobile phone and some string tuner app. At the first you may need to tune your ukulele more freguently because nylon strings and ukulele frame will take some time to settle and hold tune.

Now you are all set and ready to use you Travelele!

  • Frame is designed to fit cheap Ebay friction tuners, ones with friction washer.
  • Strings were regular nylon ukulele strings from ebay.
  • To assemble frame you need one M4 bolt, 20-30 mm long and nut, just something from junk box. Size #8 and 1" long will do just fine, I think.
  • Option to turn this to electric ukule, you need to one ukulele piezo pickup. My piezo was from ebay and about 55mm x 3 mm in size and comes with about 15cm of cable attached.

-Total cost of parts not including plastic was less than 10€
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/a7Lu7pEJsd4" ></iframe>

comments.author: danielhulbert

comments.text: Great idea but I think you should consider adding a sound board (very thin solid layer that can freely resonate) to the top of the body.  This might significantly amplify the sound.  Ideally the bridge should be structurally integrated with the sound board and not connected to any solid anchors underneath, although this might take some structural engineering work to get just right due to the loads involved.  But regardless, very nice and clever design!
comments.author: jbramel

comments.text: You are totally correct about soundboard, you can get much more sound with good resonator and i was thinking building one at some point, but  decided to use electric amplification to get more sound when needed. Now when i try to practise playing i´m not annoying everyone around me so much. I might later to update this with resonator add-on, it will require changes to current body so its not just plug-and-play on current design but should be doable. Thank you!

description.text:
This is a longer squeegee used to wipe water off of smooth surfaces. My shower doors and window are almost 24" in width so one swipe per panel is all that's needed. This assembly consists of the following components...
(2) One half printed squeegee body
(2) 6 inch metal clothes hanger rod
(1) 24 inch or longer windshield wiper (lowest cost works fine)

I was tired of using a small 8" squeegee for my shower.  I thought, if it were twice as long, I could finish in half the time.  
This is a two part print.  I used my See Me CNC Delta printer which can print taller parts than many.  There are two files, one with a base and one without.  The base is used for stability and I also placed weights on it as it was printing.  (Part moves a bit while printing, so do not hold the print in place with you hand, just let it print).   There are two holes inside used to hold the two sections together.  I used a typical metal hanger and cut two pieces and pushed into the holes.  I used a windshield wiper blade from a local auto store.  The blade was a bit difficult to slide through the slot but you can do it.  After blade insertion was complete I just trimmed the ends.  
So my wife and I have been using this thing for about 1 year.  Its awesome.  She doesn't really like the appearance but I said it matches the tent dome on the top of the shower to keep steam in (which is the best thing I've made). We've reduced the shower squeegee time from 20 seconds to 10 seconds.  This tool saves me about 1 hour of my life per year from squeegeeing the darn shower doors.  
I also added a photo of a screw up, one of the delta arms was caught by the feed tube and one axis didn't print.  Its now art on my desk.  
Great item for BB&B shelves.  
Enjoy!

It's been one year since i broke it and 3 years since i first began this project while i was studying technical product design.
I couldn't design something without putting some exccentricity to it. I took some ideas from command & conquer and the front wheel design ist a copy from a Bimota Tesi but most people identified it as an abstract Batmobile replica.

I planned it to be a GPS controlled high speed rover for slightly uneven and urban terrain.
To finish the chassis i planned to add a rear wheel system with two wheels and a full enclosure. The drive test was successful and i just needed to decrease the backlash of the steering system and secure the rims of the front wheels from slipping out.
I used a 3660 brushless motor with a 2200mah nimh battery pack and a 60A brushless esc.
Anyway, it has been been a long time since i stopped this project but now i think it isn't good to let this project die unknown on my hard drive so i decided to share my files with you as some sort of a resource to use for your own projects.
I uploaded all the original source code, so you can modify anything you like with Autodesk Inventor (and maybe Fusion 360 but i need to reinstall it to test it).

At least i hope you like it and find it useful for something.

Don't fear to ask me something.

Parts

If you want to reconstruct it you need the following parts:

(I use metric dimensions (mm) )

-A heap of M3 x 20 screws (200 should be enough)
-Another heap of M3 nuts
-A hand full of M3 x 16 screws (50 or so)
-Some M3 x 25 screws for the front wheels and some parts of the frame. (20 or more)
-2 M4 screws for the suspension system
-At least 20 "61800" (10 x 19 x 5) sealed ball bearings
-At least 4 "61902" (15 x 28 x 7) sealed ball bearings
-2 "61911" (55 x 80 x 13) sealed ball bearing for the front wheels
-4 ball joints with m3 threads
-2 meters of m3 threaded rods
-4 M8 x 80 screws
-M6 x 20 screws (20 or mode)
-4 long M6 screws to reinforce the front wheel axles
-1-2 meters of Aluminium H profiles (need to check the files)
-1-2 meters of Aluminium L profiles (need to check the files)
-I need to check the files for more specific numbers and for something i maybe forgot

What the part code means (some parts are not categorized properly):

1xx : front wheels
2xx : front forks
3xx : chassis
4xx : front fork and chassis connectors
5xx , 6xx , 8xx : suspension and rear drive parts
7xx : rear fork and chassis connectors
9xx : additional parts and structural stabilizers
10xx : outer frame
RDR_xxx : headlight and (pathetic) ultrasonic sonar system

Additional Info

-The rods for the servo steering need to be cross connected to prevent disadvantegous relaive wheel angles.

-I printed the stressed fork parts (204 & 204_MIR) out of Taulman Bridge nylon first, but due to it's elasticity which had a bad impact on steering reliability, i then switched to PMMA for it's higher rigidity.

-It is possible to flip it on it's back when you accelerate too much while turning in a close curve.

This is a replacement Heroscape Glacier (6 Hex) from the Thaelenk Tundra expansion.

It's over 151mm in length and 130mm tall, so it's a little large for the average printing bed, but I have created both a slightly-scaled version that can be printed in 2 parts (Left and Right) or a full version that can be printed in 3 parts (Top, Bottom Left, Bottom Right) for beds under 120mm, e.g. the MP Select Mini.

It was created using a Rock Outcrop sourced from Heroscapers Index of 3D Printed Stl Files and reworked in Tinkercad.

The Rock Outcrop models I've uploaded from Battle for the Underdark can be used for the smaller glaciers in Thaelenk Tundra, too.

Enjoy! ✨

This is a lightweight, transportable stand for tablets (designed for the iPad 1) which enables the user to comfortably position the device at two angles (30Â°/65Â°) on a reasonably flat surface. 
The four flat parts can be carried in the tablet's bag, and it can be assembled quickly wherever needed. 
This is the first viable version, improvements might follow.

Make sure to thoroughly clean the slides on the bridges and the grooves on the legs well before trying to put it together (keyhole-files work well)! The parts are meant to slide together with relative ease. It might be required to file down the noses on the slides, or make the grooves deeper with a file, for the parts to fit well. If they jam up when you slide them together, try wiggling a little bit around the sliding axis, and then slide them apart/file more/try again. I do not recommend clipping the bridges on - they probably wouldn't last long. The Grooves on the Legs have to face outward when you put it together. Recommended Settings: Layer height: 0.2mm
Solid layers: 4
Perimeters: 3 (0.3mm Nozzle)
Fill-in: 0.3 (hexagonal works well) Printable on a Huxley, although I had to do the legs individually. Hope someone (else) finds it useful.

description.text:
This holder is designed to be installed at the rear of your rooster, the holder has as lower profile as possible to keep it off the ground, but sadly due to Rooster antenna placement there is only so much are available, as a result, when using the standard foam landing pads this holder will come into contact with the ground, therefore I recommend using a slightly thicker foam landing pad on the quads arms.

When printing this LED holder, try to keep your support layers at 40%, this should give you some very thin supports in the LED board holding area, as shown in the attached printing pictures. If you print like this, the LED board just snaps into place perfectly (depending on LED board tolerances, you might need to slightly brush the PCB board on some light sanding paper if it wont fit)

Enjoy !!

title: Belt Tensioner for Tornado
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
remix of fessyFOO´s Belt Tensioner for Tevo Tornado X and Y-axis (20x40 profile)

The parts are meant to be used with the original pulleys.

The X-axis pulley is a 2part design with 8mm ID and an overallwidth of 10mm.
Insert the spacer (Spacer_-_ID5_OD8_L10) and you end up with a pulley for 5mm axis.
I took some Ikea "cabinet joiner" with 5MM OD and a length of ~24mm, shortened them to 20mm and used them as axis.
The puller is designed accordingly: 5(mm)a(xis)8(mm)b(earing)10(mm)h(ead)
The X-axis Tensioner Case offsets the pulley by 3mm for better belt alignment.

The Y-axis pulley is a 2part design with 4mm ID and an overallwidth of 10mm.
I used 4mm brass rod and M2.5 screws with big heads.
The puller is designed accordingly: 4(mm)a(xis)4(mm)b(earing)7(mm)h(ead)
The Y-axis Tensioner Case offsets the pulley by 6mm for better belt alignment.

The Nuts to make the actual tensioning happen are at 97%,98% and 99% of the original.

title: Osprey Suppressor Style Tracer Unit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made a tracer unit in the style of the Osprey suppressor which uses a small 7,4V LiPo battery and a couple of high brightness 5mm UV LED's to light up the tracer BB's as you are shooting them.

The suppressor consists of 3 main parts, the main body, the lid and the thread adapter.
I currently have designed a 14mm CW and a 14mm CCW thread adapter to tuse with this system, just attach it to the main body using 4x M3x30mm screws.

The lid click in place on the bottom of the unit and stays in place with a M3x10mm screw.

title: Digital torque meter with tilting screen

description.text:
Digital torque meter for rubber powered indoor model aircraft.

The screen in tilting. By modifying front panel and case some other digital scaled can be used. Tilting is really needed because LCD in digital scale is polarized to be best seen from very shallow angle.

The torque level arm is 5 cm. When scale is set to CARATs, output units of torque will be g-cm.

Extra things you'll need:

Digital scale
https://www.ebay.ca/itm/500g-x-0-01g-Digital-Pocket-Scale-Gold-Silver-Jewelry-Weight-Balance-Tool-New/282737006553?_trkparms=pageci%3A1b01d17f-0d0d-11e8-887e-74dbd1808ff7%7Cparentrq%3A7710fc271610aa144821c3e8fff9f0a6%7Ciid%3A1&_trksid=p2481888.c100675.m4236

1/8" Du-Bro collar with set screw
0.8..1 mm music wire for shaft.
1.5-3 mm brass tubing for for adaptor
Two 3x8x4 flanged ball bearing
Two AA batteries
Four M3x10 socket head screws
Four 6x2 magnets
A piece 0.013" music wire and 0.6mmx20 pin for retaining link

From digital scale following parts are used - main board with LCD screen, buttons, load cell, and battery terminals. the original wires are very thin and fragile. Replace them with longer and more strong ones.

Feel free to modify it for the parts you have available. For the next iteration I would make case wider a bit - the gap between load cell and the wall is about 0.2mm.

description.text:
Just a wall mounted filament roll hanger. Good for when you have limited space and don't want to read around behind your printer to change the roll. This makes it MUCH easier.

UPDATE (2/13/18): Added a holder with a longer neck for larger or even dual spools.

UPDATE: I finally found time to get this thing printed. Works GREAT! Even a quick and rough print gave me a good result. Made from white ABS with a 20% fill rate with a .2 mm layer thickness, it took me about two hours to print.

NOTE: The smaller hanger will only hold the smaller rolls of filament. I was going for small because I was unsure how well it would hold up for the larger ones, but now I think I'll extend it out and won't have a problem. I'll have the updated version later.

Not enough room The office I work in is tiny with lots of misc. junk inside it, meaning I have minimal room for storing filament. Fortunately, I'm able to put however many holes in the wall that I need to do R&D here, so I made a hanger to hang filament rolls on the wall behind my Ultimaker2. Also makes it much easier to monitor the roll and change it when needed. Can also let me mount store rolls on the wall and just change out the filament line when I need a different one.
No lesson No lesson

Simple wedge to help holding the proper angle while sharpening a knife on a whetstone.

You can only use this block to determine the angle, you cannot use the block while grinding.

  1. Put Knife with the degree wedge on the whetstone.
  2. Grab the Knife tight so the angle is locked
  3. Remove Wedge
  4. Go give em.
  5. Profit :-)

description.text:
The idea is to create an autonomous device, mounted on a bike, which would map the pollution in a city, for example for comparing different cycle path.

For this we use a GPS module and a particle monitor, both interfaced via serial lines.
A Raspeberry Pi (v2) and a power bank have been re-used from a former project. I also added a DHT22 sensor for temperature, it may be of some interest.
For now the design is far from being compact, mainly due to the size of the Raspberry and of the power bank.

The software part and the spec. of the sensors are stored here:
https://github.com/kif/dustair

A visualization tool based on jupyter notebooks is available in the data directory of the github project

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Printed on PLA

Assembly

6 16x2.5 screws are used to assemble the battery holder to the base.
6 12x2 screws are used to hold the SDS021 sensor and the raspberry pi.

Battery holder

There are 3 battery holder: the rear one is closed, the front one has a hole to allow the USB-power cable to enter the case.
The power bank provides the battery level monitor and the power switch which is directly accessible.

Sensor-chamber

The rear part of the case contains the SDS021 particle sensor and the DHT22 temperature & humidity sensor. The cover has 51 holes on each side for good air transit and water projection protection. The raspberry chamber is pretty well isolated from the outside.

Slider

The cover slides on the base and can closed or removed without tools to remove the USB-stick used as data storage.

title: Valify Robot Lawn Mower (concept body - under construction)

description.text:
I have been thinking about developing a robot lawnmower that is actually a “robot” a while now. What I mean by this, is that it can make its own decisions in relation to the environment and conditions. Why I think this is fun project is because I have encountered a lot of problems with the existing robot lawn mowers, they are simply not smart enough.

Features I’m looking for:
1.No perimeter wire.
2.Different driving styles (diagonal cut, pattern cut etc..)
3.3D mapping. Creates a 3D map of the the garden.
4.Know exactly where the robot is in the garden.
5.Automatic raising of mower blades if they moves too Heavy (if to low height is set.)
6.Using a camera to recognize grasses and colors.

So with this wish list I came up with the following hardware specs for this build
Jetson TX2 Development Kit
Scanse Sweep
Intel® RealSense™ Camera ZR300
2x DC Planetary Geared Motor 24 Volt med Hall IC 30-33 RPM 8mm
2x Vapex Li-Po Battery 6S 22.2V 4000mAh 25C XT60
SparkFun 9DoF
RoboClaw 2x45A ST
Emlid Reach — RTK GNSS modules
(Mower motors for the blades I have not decided yet.)

All models changes on a daily basis on my end and will not be uploaded directly.
This project is a Work-In-Progress.
Please download if you wish, but erors and bugs on bodies may be present.

I keep my ears or eyes open for useful feedback :-)

and please follow my build project blog http://valify.se

comments.text: While I find this to be interesting I think you should move the main wheels forward to be under the center of mass or near it. This will reduce the force needed to turn and hold the front up.  I don't see the ball I expect is there.  Also, If you Put the 3rd point of contact in the rear (main wheels in front of Center of Gravity) it will be rolling thru lower height grass and roll easier.

description.text:
Summary

A box to hold monster cards, standees and sheet for board game Gloomhaven.
For Unsleeved cards only (takes less space and that is how I store it).

The idea is to speed up the set up and tear down. Instead of searching individually for standees, decks and sheets, they are in one place. You can leave the sheet in the box if you are using stands with life counter.

minimum dimensions, minimum space requirement
Only 102x102 mm, fits on the printbed, uses 15-17 g of filament and prints in 45-54 minutes. Theoretically all boxes should be 163 mm high if stacked on top of each other. In practice, all of my boxes total 180 mm which is

other designs to check
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2705022 - box for sleeved cards, first design on thingieverse by by Knekkebjoern
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2797796 - box for sleeved cards, ultimate box by YY-Guys
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2507046 - standee base with life counter

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2789122 - - dice stand to track XP and HP - my own design :)

Variations

  • 3.7 mm: for monsters with small standees that fit into single layer (inside is 2.5 mm high, minimal for deck height)
  • 5.2 mm for all other monsters.
  • 14.5 mm for boss stadees and all boss sheets
  • all come in two designs, 'Gloombox2' was easier to print for me and has more space inside

Estimated number of boxes

  • Gloombox: ? (will update but I've switched to second design - Gloombox2)
  • Gloombox2: 19 x 3.7 mm, 15 x 5.2 mm. Monsters that go into 3.7 mm box: Bandit Guard, Bandit Archer, City Guard, City Archer, Vermling Shaman, Living Corpse, Living Spirit, Cultist, Giant Viper, Forest Imp, Hound, Cave Bear, Ancient Artillery, Rending Drake, Spitting Drake, Savvas Icestorm, Savvas Lavaflow, Harrower Infester, Deep Terror.
  • Boss box: fits all bosses in 4 layers.

Design notes

Walls are 2 mm wide because Slic3r will by default creates double perimeters for it, while it was creating a single perimeter (+gap fill) with anything less than 2 mm. Bottom is .5 mm - gets the job done and is ideal for the first two layer heights .32 and .2

Updates

2018-02-24: Added slide-in rail for design 'Gloombox2'. I thought the tolerance by itself would keep the lid in place but after a while some of my boxes became loose. Much better now. Design 'Gloombox' seems ok thought
2018-02-16 #2: Updated number of boxes for the design 'Gloombox2' - 19 thin ones and 15 thicker ones (was 17 and 17)
2018-02-16: Increased boss box thickness to 14.5 mm. As you can see in the photo I was missing two standees and only noticed in the end. Add the first design type box (didn't test if it fits all standees).
2018-02-11: Added .2 mm to both boxes thickness. Added second design 'Gloombox2' - prints better and has more room for standees. Added boss box.

Printer:

Anet A6

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

-

Notes:

Fits 220x220 bed. Print time: ~45' for 3.7 mm and ~54' for 5.2 mm - the whole box, not just the top or bottom.

Gloombox: I have had to use brim because the print lifts/curls around two corners of the lid, near the window for enemy stats.

Gloombox2: Prints perfectly for me

You can use 'split' function in Slic3r if this doesn't fit your bed

description.text:
Case for BrewPiLess fermentation controller. Device created by pocketmon.

See more @:
https://github.com/vitotai/BrewPiLess
https://www.homebrewtalk.com/forum/threads/brewpi-esp8266-no-need-of-rpi-and-arduino.587425/
http://www.homebrewtalk.com.br/showthread.php?t=410517

Any support questions for the electronics should be directed to one of the above links.

BOM:
1 x LCD module I2C for Arduino (https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01GPUMP9C/ref=sspa_dk_detail_0?pd_rd_i=B01E6N19YC&pd_rd_wg=YxlBx&pd_rd_r=8PV5NBY2VKRD3WBFP03Q&pd_rd_w=lO4Em&th=1)
1 x BrewManiacEx/BrewPiLess Brewshield (http://vito.tw/?p=576)
1 x 5V power supply (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5V-2A-Precision-Isolation-Bare-Plate-Switching-Power-Module-Supply-Regulator-10W/32718382292.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.hU7J7I)
3 x DS18B20 - 6 feet - temperature sensor (https://www.amazon.com/Vktech-Waterproof-Digital-Temperature-DS18b20/dp/B00EU70ZL8/ref=sr_1_cc_1?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1518125555&sr=1-1-catcorr&keywords=ds18b20+2m)
3 x Mini XLR 3 pins male socket (https://www.amazon.com/CESS-Socket-Connector-Adapter-Microphone/dp/B014EJY0JE/ref=sr_1_9?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1518125639&sr=1-9&keywords=mini+xlr+3)
3 x Mini XLR 3 pins female socket (https://www.amazon.com/CableCreation-5-PACK-Female-Connector-Microphones/dp/B01J33CF48/ref=sr_1_4?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1518125689&sr=1-4&keywords=mini+xlr+3)
1 x 2 Channel DC 5V Relay Module with Optocoupler (https://www.amazon.com/SunFounder-Channel-Optocoupler-Expansion-Raspberry/dp/B00E0NTPP4/)
1 x 10A 250V AC Rocker Switch 3 Pin IEC320 C14 Inlet Module Plug Fuse (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NWO68JI/)
Assorted screws, wires and connectors

Wall Power Outlet:
US Version: 1 x Decora-style 15A Wall Outlet (https://www.amazon.com/Eaton-Resistant-Decorator-Receptacle-125-Volt/dp/B001CE95O0/)
BR Version: 1 x Tomada dupla Fame Blanc (http://www.telhanorte.com.br/tomada-dupla-10a-250v-blanc-fame-752045/p)

OPTIONAL:
1 x microUSB female to male socket (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/22mm-mounting-diameter-Micro-USB-Female-to-Male-Silver-color/32821508236.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.EYVTJm)
1 x 5V Angel eye Power Button (https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/1-set-22mm-3v-5v-6v-12v-24v-48v-220v-Power-Symbol-Angel-Eye-Halo-Car/1428509_32794363737.html?spm=2114.12010615.0.0.525d17c8Tao44q_

There are FOUR different box designs. Files Included are:
0_BrewPiLess_Case_MOCKUP.stl - It's just a virtual mockup so you can get an idea of the final piece.
01_REV00_BPL_Lid.stl - Same top for all case designs.
02.1_REV00_BPL_US_version_Bottom_withSwitches.stl - US version with microUSB and Power buttons.
02.2_REV00_BPL_US_version_Bottom_NOSwitches.stl - US version WITHOUT microUSB and Power buttons.
02.3_REV00_BPL_BR_version_Bottom_withSwitches.stl - Brazilian version with microUSB and Power buttons.
02.4_REV00_BPL_BR_version_Bottom_NOSwitches.stl - Brazilian version WITHOUT microUSB and Power buttons.

Special thanks to Donnie Jurgensen for his patience and CAD work!

print_settings.Notes:: Supports as needed.  Some parts might need rotation for best print quality/speed/ease.

description.text:
Ripped from DestinySTLgenerator and then made printable.

The files gained this way are quite low quality and low detail so I had to model a couple of things back in myself. The "knobs" and "bolt shroud" are made as extra, print out the number you need.

I used appropriately sized hex bolts from eBay to fill the shrouds, I cut the head off the threads and just glued them on where needed. (you might have to drill out where the bolts go to make them sit flat).

You'll also want to source a short leather strap, again I got this from eBay. Scale your "Buckle" depending on what leather you bought.

The site glass was a small disc of acrylic that I got from......yup, you guessed it, eBay!

Other details you might see are painted o-rings.

Hopefully you can work it all out from the Meshmixer screen shots, I tried my best to give an exploded view that people would be able to follow.

I even included the stand I used. Original found here: "thing:1511233" the one included with mine is just scaled 135%.

Any questions just ask, hopefully I can answer.

The only known problem I had was between the "Butt" and "Body 1.2", in my print I had to cut it down, I edited the files so they should work, let me know if they don't.

Mounting the sight on the rail and then on to the body is a little tricky, dry run it a few times before trying to glue it.

description.text:
This is a mount for the XHover Win 5 frame. It will probably fit other frames too. I like to print these in TPE because it is flexible like TPU but also has a little stretch to it. I think this helps it eliminate vibrations better than TPU. It would probably still print fine in TPU though.

This was designed after another mount, but this one is shorter and keeps the camera from sticking too far out the front of the frame and should help protect it a little more.

This thing makes it easy to disonnect the balance connector on RC Lipo batteries. It is a simple device that clamps in the slot between the male and female connectors on a JST-HX connector. For most connectors you just slide the tool into place and give a gentle tug. If the plug is really on tight you can use a rocking motion to wedge the male side out.
There are 3 versions, an 8mm, 6mm and 4.5mm. The only difference is how wide the tool is. The 8mm is good for 6S batteries while the other two are helpful with batteries that have fewer cells.
Printed with PLA. 25% fill but I used 4 layers for top, bottom and sides to give maximum strength around the jaws.

First photo, from left to right:
Original Steam Controller joystick
Element Digital magnetic swappable base
My mod, printed by shapeways in black hp nylon.

Second from left to right... please dont mind the quite frankly old and worn out mouse pad.
Its the same order, but this time I've added a top to the ones that can be swapped.

WARNING: Check further text in the "post-printing" section.

Wanted to mod my steam controller joystick, with swappable joystick parts a la:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01I1G6QWA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Thought it would be easy enough to open the controller and swap, but because the SC's joystick is smaller than normal the more standard sized ones dont fit. Instead of grinding out the "joystick well" and risk destroying the front cover of the SC, I decided to modify the stl's Valve released of the SC; using the joystick models base and adding the stem, as well as a slot for the magnet.

If you want to print this and fully use it, I recommend picking up the same joystick set I did. Not only does it come with the stick tops, but you can pop the magnets out of the base. Basically, it will have everything else you need to modify your SC's joystick if you want the swappable bits like I do.

I have my print from shapeways, and...

It fits! No grinding out the chassis or toying with trimming the internal stem! However...

There are FOUR issues with this model (at least with the black hp nylon material I ordered it in, so ymmv), listed in least to most troublesome;

0: If you use the element digital kit (or one similar) that I linked, be advised that you must use the "inner most" disc magnet. The larger outer one doesnt fit and isnt a magnet anyway. Well, it does fit, but it hits the internal box before the joystick can move all the way to the edge of the chassis. This problem still somewhat exists with just the smaller one, but is a lot less noticeable.

1: The hole for the internal stick stem is too wide. It therefore is very loose and wobbles. While I will be changing this, in the interim I found adding some tape to the stem to "widen" it helped.

2: Its own stem is a bit too narrow. The same idea here could be used, but is kinda more frustrating.

3: The area where the "stem well" - the part where the joystick top goes - and the main hemisphere meet is... quite thin. So much so that it can tear apart. Two solutions.
a: I will be adjusting the model to have a beefier join. Thats really just not acceptable.
b: If you already have had this printed, I recommend using a 2 part epoxy to strengthen it as you'll most likely be using some form of adhesive to keep the magnet in place anyway.

I used a digital caliper to take measurements off the joystick base from the kit.

I used Blender to modify the stl for the joystick that Valve released.

I had to use the Decimate modifier to remove a TON of vertices, Valve's stl's have monstrously large file sizes because they are insane in terms of quality; basically made to print as is flawlessly, but not made to modify. Anyway, a 10:1 ratio brought the number of vertices down enough to be manageable for my rig, without compromising on too much quality.

From there I created a plane and use the boolean command to cut the top part of the joystick off.

Then I used a bunch of cylinders to make the "stem well", the stem, and the spot the magnet fits in.

Finally I made a curve in the shape of the cutouts along the stem, extruded that into 3d, duplicated and rotated 3 times for a total of 4 to wrap around the stem, and another boolean command to finish it up.
This is a table i designed in NX/Unigraphix and Materialise Magicks.

description.text:
Please consider leaving a tip or donating via paypal on my website: http://ferociousdesigns.co.uk/ if you like this design! All support is very much appreciated!

A simple printed replacement for the flexible Z couplers that come stock on the Anet A8. They may or may not increase print quality depending on how bad the original couplers were on your printer, and how straight your Z lead screws are.

They have a 5mm hole for the stepper shaft with a flat and a 8mm hole for the leadscrew. There is a 1mm section removed from the center of the cylinder so you can apply tension. It is best to use nylock nuts to prevent them coming loose.

I used 4x M3x10mm bolts for each and 4x M3 nuts (I didn't have enough nylock so mixed some normal M3 nuts with the nylock)

Printed at 25% cubic infill. Shouldn't need supports.
